coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic composite induced ultra-stable solid electrolyte interphase for dendrite-free lithium metal anode
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
coredata.dc:creator: Yang, Jian
Feng, Tingting
Zhi, Chen
Li, Jingzhu
Zhou, Haiping
Chen, Cheng
Song, Yaochen
Wu, Mengqiang
coredata.dc:description: Lithium metal is the most promising anode materials for the next generation lithium ion battery. However, the electrode polarization leads to the formation of dendrites and “dead lithium”, which degrades the performance of lithium metal batteries and induce a variety of security risk. The electrode polarization and lithium dendrites can be suppressed by lithium metal composite electrode. Herein, a simple and effective strategy is adopted to construct nickel and lithium bimetallic composite (NiLi-BC) electrode by a double roll process. The Ni framework inside the electrode can optimize the electric field and Li+ distribution at the electrode/electrolyte interface and induce the uniform lithium deposition. As a result, the NiLi-BC exhibits a lithium dendrite-free feature and stable cycling performance under a low overpotential (<15 mV throughout 2180 h at 1 mA cm−2 with a deposition capacity of 1 mAh cm−2). Moreover, the assembled NiLi-BC||LiFePO4 coin cell and pouch cell exhibit improved capability and stable cycling performance. Finally, the in-situ optical microscopy and in-situ Raman spectroscopy are employed to obtain a better understanding of the interfacial structure and chemical component during the Li plating and striping processes. The scheme of this study of the NiLi electrode has great practical application value.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Schematic illustration of the fabrication process of the NiLi-BC, (b-d) the optical image of the circular electrodes of Li and NiLi-BC. (c) the optical image of the NiLi-BC electrode for pouch cells . (d) the thickness of NiLi-BC, (e) the top view SEM image of NiLi-BC (f) the cross-section SEM image of NiLi-BC, (g) the cross-section EDS of NiLi-BC.

Electrochemical performance of the NiLi-BC symmetric cell and the Li symmetric cell. (a) Voltage-time profiles of the Li plating/stripping process with a cycling capacity of 1 mA h cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2. The insets in (a) present an almost constant polarization voltage from 1000 to 2000 h. (b) The comparison of voltage profiles at the cycles of 100th, 500th and 1000th, respectively. (c) The EIS spectra of the NiLi-BC symmetric cell with a cycling time evolution. (d) Voltage-time profiles with a cycling capacity of 8 mA h cm−2 at 8 mA cm−2. (e) The comparison of voltage profiles at the cycles of 100th, 200th and 300th, respectively. (f) The rate capability comparison of the NiLi-BC and Li electrode at current densities ranging from 0.5 to 10 mA cm−2.

Electrochemical performances of the NiLi-BC||Cu cell and the Li||Cu cell. (a) CEs of the two cells at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. (b) Typical galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles of the NiLi-BC electrode at 1 mA cm−2 for 1 mAh cm−2. (c) The comparison of the plating and stripping profiles for the two cells at different cycles. (d) The CEs of the two cells at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 2, 4 and 6 mAh cm−2, respectively. (e) Schematic illustration of the electric potential distribution and Li plating for the pristine Li and NiLi-BC electrodes at the electrode/electrolyte interface.

The SEM images of the pristine Li electrode after (a) 100 h, (b) 500 h and (c) 1000 h. The SEM images of the NiLi-BC electrode after (d) 100 h, (e) 1000 h and (f) 2000 h. The fixed current density is 1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. (g) The physical image of the cell for in-situ microscopic imaging. The interfacial in-situ micrographs of Li plating/stripping process of (h) the pristine Li and (i) the NiLi-BC electrodes.

The interfacial chemical components of the NiLi-BC and pristine Li electrodes. High-resolution XPS spectra of F 1 s of (a) NiLi-BC and (b) pristine Li electrodes after cycled for 100 h. (c) The interfacial F element contents of NiLi-BC and pristine Li at different test time of 100, 500 and 1000 h. (d) The in-situ Raman spectra for Li plating/striping process of the NiLi-BC electrode. The colored lines correspond to the dots in the charge/discharge curve. The electrodes are cycled at 1 mA cm−2 with 1 mAh cm−2.

Electrochemical performances of the Li||LFP and NiLi-BC||LFP coin cells: (a) a comparison of the cycling stability of the two cells at 0.2C, (b) the first galvanostatic charge and discharge curves of the two cells at 0.2C, (c) the cycling performances at 1C and (d) the rate performances from 0.1 to 5C. The electrochemical performances of the NiLi-BC||LFP pouch cells: (e) the initial charge and discharge curves and (f) the cycling performance at 0.2C.

head.ce:title: Bimetallic composite induced ultra-stable solid electrolyte interphase for dendrite-free lithium metal anode

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Materials and Energy, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC), Chengdu 611731, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC)

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Materials and Energy, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC), Chengdu 611731, PR China

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These two authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The NiLi-BC electrode forms regular interfacial electric field near the electrode surface, which is favorable to eliminate the local concentration polarization and induce the generation of the stable and long-term effective SEI during the Li plating and striping processes. As a result, the NiLi-BC electrode exhibits a Li dendrite-free feature and ultra-stable cycling performance with a low overpotential.

Lithium metal is the most promising anode materials for the next generation lithium ion battery. However, the electrode polarization leads to the formation of dendrites and “dead lithium”, which degrades the performance of lithium metal batteries and induce a variety of security risk. The electrode polarization and lithium dendrites can be suppressed by lithium metal composite electrode. Herein, a simple and effective strategy is adopted to construct nickel and lithium bimetallic composite (NiLi-BC) electrode by a double roll process. The Ni framework inside the electrode can optimize the electric field and Li+ distribution at the electrode/electrolyte interface and induce the uniform lithium deposition. As a result, the NiLi-BC exhibits a lithium dendrite-free feature and stable cycling performance under a low overpotential (<15 mV throughout 2180 h at 1 mA cm−2 with a deposition capacity of 1 mAh cm−2). Moreover, the assembled NiLi-BC||LiFePO4 coin cell and pouch cell exhibit improved capability and stable cycling performance. Finally, the in-situ optical microscopy and in-situ Raman spectroscopy are employed to obtain a better understanding of the interfacial structure and chemical component during the Li plating and striping processes. The scheme of this study of the NiLi electrode has great practical application value.

ce:section.ce:para: Nowadays, lithium ion batteries (LIBs) are indispensable to all aspects of life, including electric cars, electronic products and portable electronic devices [1]. However, after 30 years of development, the performance of LIBs has reached a bottleneck and fails to meet the continuously increasing demand for large-scale energy storage systems and power batteries [2-4]. It is conceivable that advances in LIBs technology will further drive economic growth [5,6]. Increasing the energy density of LIBs is an important solution, but usually comes at the expense of safety. Therefore, it is important and difficult for researchers to improve the energy density of LIBs and ensure the safety performance [7,8].

Numerous scientific studies have shown that lithium (Li) metal is the most promising anode materials for the next-generation high energy density storage devices (such as Li-sulfur, solid-state and Li-air) owning to its ultrahigh theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and the most negative electrochemical potential (-3.04 V versus standard hydrogen electrode) [9-11]. However, the uncontrolled growth of Li dendrites and the accumulation of “dead Li” or the corrosion of Li metal anode cause a low Coulombic efficiency (CE) of Li+ deposition/dissolution, which hinders the commercial development of rechargeable nonaqueous electrolyte Li metal battery [12]. The worst outcome is the growing dendritic metal punctures the membrane, causing cell failure and safety issues by internal short circuits [13,14]. To solve the aforementioned hindering issues of Li metal, a series of methods have been adopted by researchers, such as the optimization of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on the surface of lithium metal,[15,16] to prepare 3D composite Li metal electrode,[17-19] or prepare Li metal electrode by electrodeposition on current collectors [20,21]. Although these strategies render critical progress to enhance the reversibility of Li plating/stripping and the cycling performance of Li metal batteries, they are unsatisfied for practical applications due to the complex operating process and strict experimental conditions [22]. To better solve the Li dendrite issue, it should be first known that the Li dendrite growth is resulted by local non-uniformity of Li plating, which is caused by the concentration polarization of the electrolyte on the electrode surface [23,24]. The essence is that the electric field (EF) intensity at the electrode/electrolyte interface is different, thus affecting the Li plating rate at different positions on the electrode surface [25,26]. Therefore, the structure of the electrode could be designed to generate a substantially uniform EF at the electrode/electrolyte interface and induce the uniform Li plating [23,27-29]. The strategy could homogenize the behavior of Li plating/stripping on the electrode surface and eliminate the dendritic formation. For example, Lu et al. reported a 3D current collector of graphitic carbon nitride for dendrite-free Li metal anode [27]. Zou and co-authors developed a compartmented copper current collector to laterally direct the growth of Li dendrites [29]. Cheng et al. fabricated a 3D glass fiber modified Cu foil electrode, which redistributed the concentrated Li+ evenly and rendered the dendrite-free Li deposits [30]. However, these studies have cumbersome preparation processes and harsh experimental conditions, which are adverse to the practical application of Li metal battery. Moreover, none of the above methods can fabricate large-area electrodes to meet the technological requirements of pouch or cylindrical batteries. Therefore, how to obtain lithium dendrite-free and industry-adoptable Li metal electrode has become an urgent task at present.

Herein, based on the design principle of optimizing the EF distribution at the electrode/electrolyte interface, we design a practical and effective bimetallic composite (NiLi-BC) electrode by rolling Ni foam and Li foil. The NiLi-BC electrode forms regular interfacial EF near the electrode surface, which is favorable to eliminate the local concentration polarization and induce the generation of the stable and long-term effective SEI during the Li plating and striping processes. As a result, the NiLi-BC symmetrical cell exhibits a Li dendrite-free feature and ultra-stable cycling performance with a low overpotential (less than15 mV) throughout 2180 h cycles at 1 mA cm−2 with the limited capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. When paired with the typical LiFePO4 (LFP) cathode, the assembled NiLi-BC||LFP coin cell and pouch cell exhibit improved capacity and stable cycling performance. We employed the in-situ optical microscopy and in-situ Raman spectroscopy to further understand the interfacial electrochemical processes of Li deposition and dissection. This facile and effective strategy provides a feasible road for the engineering application of Li metal anode.

The NiLi-BC composite electrode was prepared by a simple rolling process. Primarily, the Ni foam (Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd, the purity of 99.9%) with a thickness of 200 μm was soaked in diluted hydrochloric acid under ultrasonic treatment for 10 min, and then washed for 3 times with deionized water. The cleaned Ni foam was dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 10 h. Finally, the Li foil (Shanghai Titan Technology Co., LTD, the purity of 99.99%) with a thickness of 100 μm and the cleaned Ni foam were aligned for roller compaction, and the thickness was set to 150 μm.

The microscopic surface morphology of the Li metal electrodes was characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, JSM-5900LV, JEOL). To examine the morphological changes after the designated electrochemical tests, the metal electrodes were retrieved by disassembling the tested cells in an argon-filled glove box, and then rinsed with dimethyl ether (DME, Sigma Aldrich) and dried in the transition chamber for 0.5 h to remove the residual solvent. The elemental composition of the NiLi-BC was analyzed by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) analysis was conducted with a Thermo Scientific K-α instrument using a Mg anode (monochromatic Kα X-rays at 1253.6 eV) as the source. The in-situ optical microscopy was taken with a high-definition digital electronic measurement microscope, using a mold purchased from Beijing Scistar Technology Co., LTD. In-situ Raman spectra were recorded by using Lab RAM HR Evolution (Horiba, France) using a 532 nm laser. The cells were plating/stripping at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 with a fixed capacity of 1 mAh cm−2.

The electrochemical measurements are acquired from both CR2032 half-cells and pouch cells assembled in an Ar-filled glove box (Oxygen and water content is less than 0.1 PPM). The electrodes of CR2032 coin cells are prepared by a hole punch with a diameter of 10 mm. Celgard 2400 polyethylene separator and 40 µL of electrolyte are used to assemble Li||Li, Li||Cu cells and Li||LFP full-cells. The electrolyte is 1 M Li bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI, the purity of 99%) in a cosolvent of dimethoxyethane (DME, the purity of 99%) and 1,3-dioxolane (DOL, the purity of 99%) (1:1 in volume) with 1% LiNO3 additive. The solvent and lithium salt were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The pouch cells are assembled by the layer-by-layer process. The electrolyte injection and encapsulation are completed in the glove box, and the welding of electrode tabs is completed in the drying room. The LFP electrode plates are fabricated by coating a well-mixed paste of LFP, Super P and PVDF at a weight ratio of 90:5:5 on the two sides of Al foil, followed by a drying process at 80 °C under vacuum for 12 h. The size of Li and LFP electrode plates is 4.8 cm × 5.6 cm, and the size of separator (Celgard 2400) is 5.5 cm × 6.5 cm. 1.0 M LiTFSI in DOL/ DME (V:V = 1:1) with 1.0 wt% LiNO3 is employed as the electrolyte in pouch cells (the electrolyte amount is 20 μL/mg). All the electrochemical measurements are performed on Wuhan Land CT2001A battery testing system at room temperature. The cut-off voltage is 1.0 V and the limited capacity is 1 ~ 8 mAh cm−2 for Li||Cu LMBs, and the voltage range is 2.7–4.2 V for Li||LFP full cell. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopies (EIS) were carried out using PARSTAT 4000 A electrochemical workstation in the frequency range of 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz.

The schematic diagram of the procedure for the NiLi-BC electrode synthesis is presented in Fig. 1 a. The soft Li foil is rolled into the pores of Ni foam andthe NiLi-BC with 3D texture is formed. The Ni framework inside the composite electrode improves the mechanical strength of the electrode while retaining the plasticity of the electrode, which is conducive to improving its processability. The low resistivity (
ρ
) of Ni (
ρ
Ni
= 6.84 × 10-8 Ω m <
ρ
Li
= 1.08 × 10-5 Ω m) can effectively improve the conductivity of the composite electrode and reduce the polarization of the electrode. The electrode prepared after roller pressing is further cut into small circular pieces with a diameter of 10 mm for half-cells. Fig. 1b shows an optical image of Li and NiLi-BC electrode, which shows a significant difference between the two electrodes. The better metallic luster of NiLi-BC is due to the roller treatment, which exposes the fresh Li to the outer layer. The fresh Li also contributes to the formation of SEI films on the electrode surface during Li plating. The NiLi-BC can be well processed into the electrode of pouch cells due to the Ni framework inside the composite electrode. As shown in Fig. 1c, the pristine Li on the surface of the Ni foam can be clearly seen. The thickness of NiLi-BC is 196 μm measured by the helical micrometer is near to 189 μm measured by SEM (Fig. 1d and f), and the Li layer on NiLi-BC is about 70 μm. The thickness of Li foil is ~ 81 μm and presented in Fig. S1 (supporting information). The top view SEM image of NiLi-BC (Fig. 1e) shows a smooth surface, which is favorable to the dendrite-free plating of Li metal electrodes. In order to understand the distribution of Li and Ni in the electrode more intuitively, the cross section EDS of the NiLi-BC electrode is presented in Fig. 1g (the region of O element can well reflect the distribution of Li). It is clearly that the Li metal enters the pores of Ni foam under the pressing pressure. The Ni framework acts as a mechanical support for the Li metal and ensures an internal high-speed conductive network.

The symmetrical coin cells (CR2032-type) with two identical NiLi-BC electrodes are assembled to evaluate the structural stability of the NiLi-BC electrode during galvanostatic cycling. To standardize the test, control cells are fabricated using pristine Li foil anode. The symmetrical cells are subjected to a typical Li plating/stripping process with different current density and different fixed areal capacity. Fig. 2 a is the voltage–time profiles of the Li plating/stripping process with a cycling capacity of 1 mA h cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2 (the utilization rate of Li is ~ 7%). In the early stage, the overpotential of NiLi-BC based symmetrical cell gradually decreased to less than 15 mV due to an activation process for the electrode,[31,32] and then maintained ultra-highly stable within 2180 h. As can be seen from the insets in Fig. 2a, the overpotential of Li deposition/stripping at 2000 h is still less than 20 mV. In contrast, the Li symmetrical cell shows an obvious increase in overpotential as the test time increases, which is more than 100 mV after 1000 h. Fig. 2b compares the voltage–time variation curves of the two symmetric cells at 100 h, 500 h and 1000 h, respectively. It can be obviously observed that the NiLi-BC symmetric cells have much better stable overvoltage. Fig. 2c shows the EIS of NiLi-BC symmetric cells with the time evolution. As can be seen, the interfacial resistance of the fresh cell is 78 Ωand then slightly decreases to 70 Ω after 500 h, corresponding to the initial overpotential reduction of the electrode. As the plating/stripping time increases, the interface impedance increases slightly, reaching 70 Ω, 80 Ω, and 88 Ω at 1000 h, 1500 h, and 2180 h, respectively. In contrast, the impedance value increases more rapidly with the extension of cycle time, compared with that of NiLi-BC symmetric cells, as indicated in Fig. S2. When the Li plating capacity is further increased to 8 mAh cm−2 at the current density of 8 mA cm−2 (the utilization rate of Li is ~ 55.6%), the NiLi-BC electrode also shows a more stable stripping/plating overpotential within 250 mV during the whole cycles (~550 h), indicating the uniform plating of NiLi-BC electrodes (Fig. 2d). Comparatively, large fluctuant overpotentials are detected for the pristine Li electrode during 100 h. Fig. 2e illustrates the voltage–time curves of the two symmetrical cells at 100, 200 and 300 h. It is obvious that the overvoltage of the NiLi-BC symmetrical cells remain almost unchanged while the overvoltage of Li symmetrical cells increases significantly. The cycling performance at a higher current density (2 and 4 mA cm−2) is shown in Fig. S3a and S3b, the NiLi-BC electrode can maintain the polarization voltage of ~ 15 mV over more than 1200 h while the pristine Li electrode can only show a poor stability. The voltage–time profiles of the Li plating/stripping process with a cycling capacity of 2 mA h cm−2 at 2 mA cm−2 is presented in Fig. S3c. The obvious difference in these profiles reflects that the pristine Li anode has a nonuniform Li deposition and irregular dendrites growth, while the NiLi-BC electrode has a positive effect on Li plating and striping process. A comparison of our work with the state-of-the-art (within 2 years) Li metal anode is presented in Table S1. It is obvious that the NiLi-BC electrode obtained here has a significant superiority over those reported results. The rate capability of the NiLi-BC and Li electrodes is compared by cycling the symmetric cells at current densities ranging from 0.5 to 10 mA cm−2 with a constant Li-stripping/plating capacity of 1 mA h cm−2 (Fig. 2f). Voltage profiles of the NiLi-BC symmetric cell show that there is very little voltage fluctuation at each current density. The values of voltage hysteresis (the sum of the overpotentials for Li stripping and plating) are 40, 50, 80, 200, 250, and 300 mV at current densities of 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 mA cm−2, respectively. The steady changes in voltage hysteresis with both current density and cycling time point to the good rate capability and stability of the NiLi-BC electrode. In contract, during the high current density of 6 mA cm−2, the overpotential of the pristine Li anode increases wildly, suggesting the large kinetic impedance for nonuniform Li plating/stripping.

To demonstrate the sustainability of the NiLi-BC electrode, we assemble asymmetric cells (Li or NiLi-BC vs Cu foil) to compare the CE, which refers to the ratio of the amount of Li stripping versus the amount of Li plating. The cells are cycled at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 with a fixed depositing capacity from 1 to 8 mAh cm−2, and the charge process is controlled by a cut-off voltage at 1.0 V. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the Li||Cu cell exhibits stable CEs (~99%) within 100 cycles and then the CEs shows a downward trend, and the CE is only 75% after 200 cycles. By contrast, the NiLi-BC||Cu cell reaches a steady CE of ~ 99% in 2 cycles and remained ultra-stable until 600 cycles. The voltage profiles of the NiLi-BC||Cu cell at selected cycles (1st, 100th, 200th, 300th, 400th and 500th) are presented in Fig. 3b, exhibiting an approximately constant voltage hysteresis of 20 ~ 30 mV for 500 cycles. Fig. 3c compares the selected voltage–time curves of the two asymmetric cells. It seen that the NiLi-BC||Cu cell has a lower reversibility than that of the Li||Cu cell in the first cycle due to the electrode activation process, but subsequently, it exhibits a higher reversibility and a low voltage hysteresis compared to Li||Cu cell, especially after 200 cycles. The Li plating and stripping behaviors of the NiLi-BC and Li electrodes are further tested at a fixed current densities of 1.0 mA cm−2 with different capacities from 2.0 to 6.0 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 3d). The corresponding voltage–time polarization curves at different area capacity are presented in Fig. S4. Obviously, the NiLi-BC||Cu cell exhibits a stable Li plating/stripping process at various applied fixed areal capacities, and its stability is much better than that of the Li||Cu cell. It can be concluded that the NiLi-BC electrode not only has an effect on Li deposition/stripping of itself, but also affects the kinetic process of Li+ on the surface of Cu electrode.

To explain the superior performance of the NiLi-BC electrode, we propose a mechanism of the different electric potential distributions for the pristine Li and the NiLi-BC electrodes, which are illustrated in Fig. 3e. The surface of the pristine Li electrode is prone to uneven nucleation and the growth of Li dendrites, which may destroy the EF distribution near the electrode and lead to the aggregation of Li+ near the dendrites and Li nuclei, resulting in a faster Li plating rate in this area and further accelerates the growth of dendrites and the generation of dead Li. However, the NiLi-BC electrode can induce a uniform distribution of EF near the electrode and leads to a uniform local concentration of Li+. The uniform and stable Li plating/striping processes maintain the stability of the SEI structure, which is the key factor to the ultra-long cycle stability and ultra-high CE of the NiLi-BC electrode.

In Fig. 4 , the morphology evolution of a pristine Li metal electrode and a NiLi-BC electrode during cycling provides strong evidence for the different electrochemical performance at a fixed current density of 1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. After 100 h (Fig. 4a and S5a), the blade-like Li-dendrites, accompanied by few of holes, can be obviously detected on the pristine Li electrode surface, which are the result of uneven Li deposition. After cycling to 500 h (Fig. 4b and S5b), the blade-like Li-dendrites gradually evolved into thicker sheets and the top showed obvious convex particles. There are increasing holes and slight cracks on the electrode surface. When cycling to 1000 h (Fig. 4c and S5c), the surface of the pristine Li electrode is covered by chunks of “dead” Li, accompanied by large cracks, which corresponds to the sharp attenuation of Li symmetric cell performance and the increase of electrode polarization in Fig. 2a. On the contrary, the NiLi-BC electrode shows a distinct surface morphology without apparent Li dendrite growth (Fig. 4d-f and S5d-f). The surface of the NiLi-BC electrode is covered with a semi-transparent SEI film after cycling 100 h, and no obvious Li dendrite can be seen in the inner layer of the electrode (Fig. 4d and S5d). Even after 1000 h, the electrode surface is still covered with a clear SEI film (Fig. 4e and S5e). Thus, it can be concluded that the NiLi-BC electrode induces the generation of the ultra-stable SEI and inhibits the growth of Li dendrites, thus ensuring the steady progress of Li plating and striping (refer to Fig. 2a). When the cycling time increases up to 2000 h (Fig. 4f and S5f), the surface of the NiLi-BC electrode shows a smooth surface, which is different from that of the pristine Li electrode surface and indicates no dead Li is formed. In addition, the SEM images of the NiLi-BC and Li electrodes during long cycles at the current density of 2 mA cm−2 with a plating capacity of 2 mAh cm−2 are presented in Fig. S6, which also reflect the smooth and dendrite-free surface of the NiLi-BC electrode. Moreover, the in-situ optical microscopy is applied to further investigate the structure evolution of the electrode/electrolyte interface during the Li plating and stripping process at 1 mA cm−2 with 1 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 4g-i). The test is carried out by assembling a symmetrical cell with a dedicated in-situ optical microscopic imaging mold (Fig. 4g).

In Fig. 4h, a Li dendrite can be clearly seen on the plating electrode of the pristine Li after plating 20 min, and the Li dendrite continue grows as the plating time increases. In the process of stripping, obvious Li dendrites also appeared on the opposite electrode, and a large amount of “dead-Li” is suspended in the electrolyte. The Li dendrites on the two electrodes grow opposite, eventually causing the battery to fail by a short circuit. In contrast, a stable interfacial electrochemical process was observed for the NiLi-BC electrode, and no significant dendrites were produced during Li plating except for the slight change of electrode thickness. The dynamic video of Li plating can be seen in Video S1 and S2 online, from which the structure evolution process of the two electrodes surface can be seen intuitively.

To investigate the chemistry at the interface of the NiLi-BC and the pristine Li electrodes, XPS was used to study the interface after 100 h galvanostatic cycles at the stripping state in Li||Li coin cells. Fig. 5 a shows high-resolution XPS spectra of the NiLi-BC electrode, from which LiF (684.9 eV in the F 1 s spectrum) and -C-F (688.4 eV) were observed [33]. In contrast, the XPS spectra of the pristine Li electrode is presented in Fig. 5b. The peak strength at 684.9 eV can reflect a lower LiF content on the surface than that of the NiLi electrode. It has been reported that LiF has a positive contribution to form stable SEI [1,34].

The interfacial F element compositions of the NiLi-BC and the pristine Li electrodes at different cycling time of 100, 500 and 1000 h are presented in Fig. 5c. The current density is 1 mA cm−2 with a fixed capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. The F content at the interface of the NiLi-BC electrode at 100, 500 and 1000 h are 7.44, 8.15 and 8.47 atom%, respectively. The small fluctuation of F element reflects the high stability of the interface SEI. By contrast, the interfacial F content at different test time of the pristine Li is 3.74, 5.02 and 9.38 atom%, respectively. The increasing F content corresponds to the continuous generation of new SEI on the surface of the pristine Li electrode. To further demonstrate the effect of the NiLi-BC electrode on the Li plating and striping, we recorded the in-situ Raman spectra as shown in Fig. 5d (3 min/time at a plating/striping current density of 1 mA cm−2 with the capacity of 1 mAh cm−2). Li plating begins at the black dot and Li stripping starts at the pink dot. The main peaks of the Raman spectra are relative to the electrolyte of LiTFSI and the solvent, and the appeared peak at ~ 550 cm−1 should be attributed to LiF. The selected local Raman spectra of LiF can be clearly seen in the selected view of Fig. 5d. At the beginning of the plating process, the LiF peak at 550 cm−1 is not obvious, but starts to appear in the following Li plating process, owing to the forming of SEI. While in the Li stripping process, the intensity of LiF peak did not change significantly, which confirms that a stable SEI was formed on the electrode surface during Li stripping process.

The NiLi-BC||LFP coin cells and pouch cells were tested to evaluate the commercial application of the NiLi-BC electrode. As can be seen from Fig. 6 a, the NiLi-BC||LFP coin cell presents higher capacity and better stability than Li||LFP coin cell. After 95 cycles, the NiLi-BC||LFP maintained a discharge capacity of 142 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 94.6%. The EIS curves of the two fresh coin cells are shown in Fig. S7, and it can be seen that the NiLi-BC||LFP coin cell exhibits smaller resistance of ~ 40 Ωthan that of Li||LFP cell (~60 Ω). The high ionic conductivity is an important reason for the high specific capacity and better cycling stability of the NiLi-BC||LFP coin cell. Fig. 6b is the initial charge and discharge curves of the two coin cells at 0.2C. The specific charge/discharge capacities of the NiLi-BC||LFP cell are 155 mAh g−1 and 149 mAh g−1, and the initial CE reach 96%. By contrast, the initial CE of pristine Li||LFP coin cell is 91% (the initial charge and discharge specific capacity is 159 and 146 mAh g−1). From Fig. 6c, the NiLi-BC||LFP coin cell exhibits a better long cycling performance at 1C, which maintains a capacity of more than 100 mAh g−1 even after 500 cycles. In addition, the rate performance of the NiLi-BC||LFP coin cell is also much better than that of pristine Li||LFP (Fig. 6d). The discharge specific capacities of the NiLi-BC||LFP coin cell at 0.1C to 5C are 148.4, 154, 150, 141, 128 and 105 mAh g−1, respectively. Compared with the pristine Li||LFP cell, a much higher discharge capacity of the NiLi-BC||LFP cell can be retained especially at a high rate. The improved rate performance of the NiLi-BC||LFP cell can be ascribed to the fast electron and Li+ transport in NiLi-BC anode. The NiLi-BC||LFP pouch cell is also assembled and tested to verify the practical value of NiLi-BC. In Fig. 6e, the initial charge and discharge capacity is 150 and 142 mAhg−1 with a high initial CE of 94.6%. The cycling behavior and the CE of the NiLi-BC||LFP pouch cell at a current density of 0.2C at room temperature are shown in Fig. 6f, which delivered a suppressed capacity decline from 142 to 140 mAh g−1 at the first 10 cycles and then gradually decayed to 110 mAh g−1 after 23 cycles. The above results demonstrate that the NiLi-BC electrode has considerable practical potential.

In summary, we design a practical and effective NiLi-BC electrode based on the principle of optimizing the EF distribution at electrode electrolyte interface. The obtained NiLi-BC electrode has a positive effect on Li deposition/deposition process: 1) induces the generation of the ultra-stable and long-term effective SEI, which can well inhibit the growth of Li dendrites; 2) induces the uniform distribution of EF near the electrode; 3) inhibits the local concentration polarization near the electrode surface, which contributes to uniform Li deposition. As a result, the NiLi-BC exhibits Li dendrite-free features and stable cycling performance with a low overpotential (<15 mV) throughout 2180 h cycles at 1 mA cm−2 with the limited capacity 1 mAh cm−2. The long cycle stability and low overpotential of Li deposition are advantages compared with existing reports. When paired with the typical LFP cathode, the assembled NiLi-BC||LFP coin cell and pouch cell exhibit improved capability and considerable cycling performance. In-situ optical microscope and in-situ Raman spectra are used to analyze the evolution of electrode/electrolyte interface during Li plating and stripping process. The results demonstrate that the NiLi-BC electrode can indeed induce the generation of the ultra-stable and long-term effective SEI and can well inhibit the growth of Li dendrites. The prepared NiLi-BC electrode has a great practical application value. This practical strategy provides a new approach to induce homogeneous nucleation and depress dendrite growth of the Li anode.
